description: User accounts allowing weak passwords like password123 or admin without complexity requirements minimum length special characters or uppercase enforcement across systems and applications
Multi-factor authentication not enabled for VPN remote access privileged accounts or administrative interfaces requiring only username and password for authentication
Sensitive data including customer information credit cards or personal health information stored in plaintext databases or transmitted over networks without TLS SSL encryption
System audit logs for user access authentication privileged operations or data access not enabled collected or retained for security monitoring and forensic investigation
Operating systems applications or firmware missing critical security patches months behind update schedules with no vulnerability management or patch deployment process
Excessive users granted domain administrator root or privileged access rights beyond job requirements without justification or periodic review of permissions
Physical access controls to server rooms data centers or secure areas using weak door codes badge readers or locks with inadequate monitoring
Third-party vendors suppliers or service providers processing sensitive data without security assessments due diligence reviews or contractual security requirements
Information security incident response plan procedures playbooks or escalation processes not documented tested or communicated to security operations teams
Backup systems failing corrupted or incomplete with no monitoring validation testing or offsite storage for disaster recovery purposes
DevOps team IT staff or administrators using shared admin accounts with same username and password distributed via Slack email to access production servers databases
Account passwords not rotated for extended periods 12 to 24 months without password aging policy expiration enforcement or change requirements
Default manufacturer passwords admin admin or root root remaining unchanged on network devices routers switches firewalls or applications after installation
Account lockout policy not configured allowing unlimited failed login attempts enabling brute-force password attacks against user or service accounts
Dormant user accounts for terminated employees contractors or former staff remaining active enabled with access to systems applications or data
Users granted more access permissions file shares database tables or application functions than required for job role violating least privilege principle
Periodic access rights reviews user recertification or permission audits not performed annually or quarterly to validate appropriate access levels
Sensitive data transmitted over networks without TLS 1.2 SSL encryption using HTTP FTP or unencrypted protocols exposing data to interception
Confidential data customer records or payment information stored in plaintext on disk drives databases or file servers without encryption at rest
Backup tapes drives or cloud storage containing sensitive production data not encrypted enabling data theft if media lost stolen or compromised
Removable media USB drives external hard drives or thumb drives allowed without restrictions endpoint controls or monitoring enabling data exfiltration
Data loss prevention DLP controls not implemented to detect prevent or alert on sensitive data being emailed uploaded or transferred outside organization
AWS S3 buckets Azure blob storage or cloud resources publicly accessible on internet allowing anonymous downloads of sensitive files or data
API keys authentication tokens or database passwords embedded hardcoded in source code repositories scripts or configuration files visible in GitHub
Network firewall rules missing misconfigured or allowing any any traffic without segmentation between production development or untrusted networks
Unnecessary network services SSH RDP FTP or management ports exposed to internet without firewall filtering or IP whitelisting restrictions
Production and development networks not segregated using VLANs subnets or firewall zones allowing lateral movement across environments
Wireless networks using WEP weak encryption or no password protection allowing network eavesdropping or unauthorized access to corporate systems
Endpoint protection antivirus EDR or malware detection not installed or virus definitions not updated on workstations servers or laptops
Operating systems applications or database software running outdated versions 6 to 12 months behind current patches with known critical vulnerabilities
End-of-life software Windows Server 2008 Oracle 11g or Java 7 still in production without vendor support security patches or updates
Vulnerability scans using Nessus Qualys or OpenVAS not performed regularly monthly or quarterly to identify security weaknesses in infrastructure
Annual penetration testing ethical hacking or red team exercises not conducted to validate security controls identify exploit paths or weaknesses
Security awareness training phishing education or safe computing practices not provided to employees contractors or new hires annually or quarterly
Employees clicking on simulated phishing emails entering credentials on fake login pages or opening malicious attachments during security tests
Pre-employment background screening criminal checks or employment verification not performed for new hires with access to sensitive data or systems
Non-disclosure agreements confidentiality agreements or data protection clauses not signed by employees contractors vendors or third parties
Personal devices iPhones Android tablets or laptops accessing corporate email or data without MDM Intune or security controls enrollment
Laptop computer or mobile device theft loss or misplacement containing unencrypted sensitive data customer information or corporate credentials
Employees leaving computer workstations unlocked unattended in open offices allowing unauthorized physical access to systems or data
Data center server room or network closet unlocked accessible to cleaning staff visitors without badge readers logging or escort requirements
Visitor access to office buildings secure areas not recorded logged or requiring escort by authorized employees with sign-in sign-out procedures
Security cameras video surveillance or CCTV not installed in server rooms entrance lobbies or sensitive areas for physical security monitoring
IT asset inventory register or CMDB not maintained tracking servers workstations network devices software licenses or hardware purchases
Unapproved SaaS applications cloud services Dropbox Slack or tools in use bypassing IT procurement security reviews or vendor assessments
Sensitive data not labeled classified or tagged as confidential public internal enabling appropriate handling retention or access controls
Data retention schedules disposal timelines or archive policies undefined for email documents databases backups enabling regulatory compliance
Hard drives storage media or decommissioned servers not securely wiped using DBAN shredded or destroyed before disposal recycling donation
Third-party vendors SaaS providers or suppliers not undergoing security assessments questionnaires SOC 2 reviews before processing sensitive data
Vendor agreements contracts or MSAs missing security requirements data protection clauses incident notification SLAs or right to audit provisions
Ongoing vendor compliance monitoring security posture reviews annual attestations or SOC 2 report validation not tracked by procurement teams
Multi-tenant cloud environments AWS RDS shared databases or containerized infrastructure without tenant isolation network segmentation or access controls
Incident response plan security breach procedures ransomware playbooks or escalation workflows not documented tested or distributed to SOC teams
Security incidents breaches or suspicious activity not escalated reported to management legal compliance or executive leadership within required timelines
Digital forensics tools memory imaging disk analysis or log correlation capabilities missing from security operations preventing incident investigation
Data breach notification procedures customer communication regulatory reporting to HHS FTC or state attorneys general undefined or not tested
Disaster recovery plan business continuity procedures or failover runbooks not documented tested or validated annually for ransomware natural disasters
Recovery point objective RPO recovery time objective RTO or maximum tolerable downtime MTD not defined documented or aligned with SLAs
Backup restoration processes never tested validated or rehearsed quarterly resulting in corrupted failed or incomplete recovery during outages
Critical systems databases or network components without redundancy high availability clustering load balancing or failover creating single points of failure
Production system changes deployments or configuration updates not following approval process CAB review testing rollback procedures or documentation
Source code not peer reviewed for security vulnerabilities SQL injection XSS or hardcoded credentials before deployment to production environments
System audit logs authentication events privileged operations or data access not enabled configured or collected on servers applications databases
Security logs SIEM alerts or IDS notifications not reviewed monitored or analyzed by SOC analysts enabling undetected breaches
Audit logs deleted purged or rotated before compliance retention periods HIPAA 6 years SOC 2 7 years expiring forensic evidence
Security information and event management SIEM Splunk QRadar or log aggregation platform not implemented for centralized monitoring correlation alerting
Web applications or APIs vulnerable to SQL injection attacks allowing attackers to manipulate database queries extract data or execute malicious commands
Cross-site scripting XSS vulnerabilities in web forms input fields or URL parameters enabling attackers to inject malicious JavaScript steal session cookies
Cross-site request forgery CSRF protection tokens not implemented allowing attackers to execute unauthorized actions on behalf of authenticated users
Applications deserializing untrusted data from JSON XML or pickle formats enabling remote code execution privilege escalation or denial of service
XML external entity XXE injection vulnerabilities in SOAP REST APIs or XML parsers allowing file disclosure SSRF or denial of service attacks
Authentication mechanisms session management or credential storage using weak algorithms MD5 SHA1 or insecure session tokens enabling account takeover
Direct object references in URLs exposing internal IDs database keys allowing unauthorized access to resources files or user data
Default configurations error messages stack traces or debug modes enabled in production exposing sensitive information system architecture or credentials
Sensitive information credit cards SSNs or passwords exposed in URL parameters logs error messages or browser cache
Application security events authentication failures authorization violations or suspicious activity not logged monitored or alerted enabling undetected attacks
API endpoints REST services or GraphQL interfaces without rate limiting throttling enabling brute-force attacks credential stuffing or denial of service
API authorization checks not validating user permissions for object access allowing horizontal privilege escalation accessing other users data
APIs returning excessive data unnecessary fields or complete database records enabling information disclosure reconnaissance or data scraping
API traffic credentials or sensitive payloads transmitted over HTTP without TLS SSL encryption exposing data to interception man-in-middle attacks
API versioning deprecation strategy or backward compatibility not implemented causing breaking changes for integrations or downstream applications
GraphQL introspection queries enabled in production exposing entire schema object types fields enabling reconnaissance for targeted attacks
GraphQL queries without depth limiting complexity analysis or query cost calculation enabling denial of service through nested resource-intensive queries
Docker containers running in privileged mode with host access unrestricted capabilities or root permissions violating container isolation principle
Docker daemon socket exposed mounted or accessible to containers enabling container breakout host system compromise or privilege escalation
Container images not scanned for vulnerabilities malware or misconfigurations using Trivy Clair Snyk before deployment to production registries
Kubernetes role-based access control RBAC not configured granting excessive cluster-admin permissions to service accounts or users
Kubernetes secrets API keys database passwords stored in plain text ConfigMaps or environment variables without encryption secrets management vault
Kubernetes network policies not implemented allowing unrestricted pod-to-pod east-west traffic enabling lateral movement after container compromise
AWS Lambda Azure Functions or serverless IAM roles granted excessive permissions s3 full access or admin rights violating least privilege
Serverless functions without execution timeout or memory limits enabling denial of wallet attacks through resource exhaustion or infinite loops
AWS IAM Azure AD policies using wildcard permissions asterisk on resources actions enabling privilege escalation or unauthorized access
AWS root account administrative IAM users or privileged roles not enforcing multi-factor authentication MFA for console API access
S3 bucket versioning Azure blob soft delete not enabled preventing recovery from accidental deletion ransomware or malicious file overwrites
Cloud storage RDS EBS volumes not encrypted using KMS customer-managed keys enabling data exposure if snapshots backups compromised
SAML single sign-on SSO implementations not validating digital signatures certificate chains enabling authentication bypass or XML signature wrapping attacks
OAuth 2.0 OpenID Connect redirect URI not validated against whitelist enabling authorization code theft open redirect attacks
JSON Web Tokens JWT not validating signatures using weak algorithms none or shared secrets enabling token forgery session hijacking
Session identifiers not regenerated after authentication login enabling session fixation attacks where attacker sets victim session ID beforehand
